name.text: 15.2.1.5 Computing COM for multiple point masses

questiontext.text:
Example

Obtain an equation for the location of the centre of mass of two objects of masses \(m_1\) and \(m_2\):

  1. located at distances \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) respectively, as shown part (a) of the Figure below.
  2. positioned on opposite sides of the origin as shown in part (b) of the Figure below.

Referring to part (a) of the above Figure, we first write down an expression for the sum of the individual moments: The total mass is \(m_1 + m_2\) and the moment of the total mass is \((m_1 + m_2) \times \bar{x}\)

The moment of the total mass is equal to the sum of the moments of the individual masses. The equation satisfied by \(\bar{x}\) is

\((m_1+m_2)\bar{x} = m_1x_1+m_2x_2\), so \(\bar{x}=\dfrac{m_1x_1+m_2x_2}{m_1+m_2}\)

However, this is precisely what would have been obtained if, when working out the moment of a mass, we use its coordinate (which takes account of sign) rather than using its distance from the origin.

For the second case, as depicted in part (b) of the figure, the mass \(m_1\) positioned on the left-hand side has a turning effect opposite to that of the mass \(m_2\) positioned on the right-hand side. To take account of this difference we use a minus sign when determining the moment of \(m_1\) about the origin. This gives a total moment

\(\qquad -(m_1x_1)+(m_2x_2)\)

leading to

\(\qquad (-m_1x_1+m_2x_2)=(m_1+m_2)\bar{x}\qquad\)so \(\qquad\bar{x}=\dfrac{-m_1x_1+m_2x_2}{m_1+m_2}\)

However, this is precisely what would have been obtained if, when working out the moment of a mass, we use its coordinate (which takes account of sign) rather than using its distance from the origin.

The above formulae can be generalised very easily to deal with the general situation of \(n\) masses, \(m_1, m_2, \dots, m_n\) located at coordinate positions \(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n\) and is given in the Key Point below.

Key Point

The centre of mass of individual masses \(m_1, m_2, \dots, m_n\) located at positions \(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n\) is \[\bar{x}=\dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^n m_i x_i}{\sum_{i=1}^n m_i}\]
